project.projectDescription: A data science professor from the University of X wants to examine what causes students’ math scores. There were 1000 thousand students participating in this survey. Some relevant information was collected through the survey.
project.dataDescription: This dataset is from https://www.kaggle.com/spscientist/students-performance-in-exams Name of data: Student Performance in Exams Format: csv file Source: https://www.kaggle.com/spscientist/students-performance-in-exams Description of Attributes: Gender: Nominal data Race/Ethnicity: Nominal data Parental Level of Education: Ordinal data Lunch: Nominal data Test Preparation: Nominal data Math Score: Qualitative data Reading Score: Qualitative data Writing Score: Qualitative data
project.researchQuestion: 1. If the student’s parents have good degrees, do they have same math scores? 2. What is the risk difference between prepared or unprepared for getting higher math scores? 3. Comparing lunch and gender, which is a better influence for the student’s math scores?
project.conclusion: It is not surprised that there are a couple of factors affecting students’ math scores. Apparently, the parental level of education is one of the key causes to impact the math score. Education is really a big problem for many students and families. A higher math score is not guaranteed to decide the future of a student, but it can reflect how much you have learned from the class. A good family education background is more likely to make a student study better.
